item.title: Leigh Saufley - 2012-10-13 09:36:57
item.content:encoded: Get off your adorable but lazy tuckas and move this ahead. No more beta! The economy is starting to pick up. Internet and web design, illustration, and art are getting to be mandatory for most businesses. Opportunities will pop up. Get ready!!!! item.title: Palaneseya Chappelle - 2013-09-29 07:54:41
item.content:encoded:
Hello, my name is Palaneseya Chappelle, I saw your website and decided to contact you. I am an independent film director, screenwriter and film producer and I have a horror film project, of which I am looking for everyone to support. My film project is entitled, "Agenda 21", about a group of friends who are subjected to unimaginable horror by demonic, alien beings. The project is currently accepting pledges on Indiegogo.com for it to go into production.
Agenda 21 is a great, horror film and so I know I don't know you personally, but I am asking, for you to please support my work as a young, female filmmaker and support and pledge to this horror film project. We have excellent rewards for those who pledge, including Agenda 21 memorabilia and even the chance to be an extra IN the film, as well as associate and executive producer credits in the film and on all marketing materials. I have posted the link to the film's crowdfunding campaign below and I am asking, if you're a true fan of horror, indie horror, please pledge to this film project, it would mean so much to me as a young filmmaker. Thank you so much and I look forward to your pledging to this horror project. Thank you.
Palaneseya Chappelle
Agenda 21 Crowdfunding link:

item.title: Bridget MacMillan - 2014-02-06 16:07:40
item.content:encoded:
Hi Ben,
I am an internal, corporate recruiter with Isobar. I came across your profile on Linked-In.
At Isobar we create enterprise applications and digitally-centered marketing campaigns for the web, mobile devices and social media. Some of our clients include Adidas, Marc Jacobs, HBO, Avis, Royal Caribbean, Lego and many others.
We are working on some interesting projects within our offices and we are looking for an developer that has strong Flash, HTML5 and other presentation layer technologies to join our Boston team. You can check out our work at http://www.isobar.com/us/work If you are interested in having a conversation, please let me know a good time to reach you. I appreciate your consideration and look forward to your response. Thank you,

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: bensaufley
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickies to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: In the face of your empire, I think I'd rather just wait in the car…
item.dc:creator: bensaufley
item.content:encoded: Just as with my last post, I don't really feel like talking about last night's brutal loss. As a new fan, and a soccer neophyte, I don't know that I have too much to say, there. What I want to talk about – briefly, this time, I promise – is the Krafts, and this bizarre dichotomy between the Revolution and the Patriots. I grew up a Patriots fan. I've probably mentioned that; I'm not going to check. My point is that my love for the Patriots and my love for the Revolution have no reason to be at odds with one another. Yet all season, as I've shown up for Revolution games at Gillette Stadium (mostly during the Patriots' offseason), I've been greeted by the Patriots swoosh, images of pigskins, and promotional signage for a season long-over, or long-to-begin. I understand that the Patriots are the moneymaker here, especially considering the Revs' contention for this season's Wooden Spoon. But one day a week, Gillette Stadium is Revolution Stadium. It is owned by the Revolution's owners, and the people who come here are here for a Revolution game – a soccer game. Yet this signage everywhere just serves as an unwelcome reminder, whispering in our ear: "This isn't your stadium." "This isn't the intended use of this stadium." And now, here comes the 2011-2012 Patriots season, and the Revolution are playing on NFL lines, kicking off from the center of the Patriots swoosh, visitors in their own stadium. I can only imagine how a player must feel, to be treated like this by his ownership, and frankly, to be embarrassed like this in front of other teams. But players are paid to do what they're told, at the end of the day, and this isn't about the players' feelings.[ref]Though I can imagine a series of mental blows like this would reasonably affect one's performance on the field.[/ref] I, on the other hand, have paid decent money to see top-class American soccer. And here I am, watching the Crew's Tom Heinemann, and thinking, "Boy, he's a first down's length offside." When I first learned of the relationship between the Patriots and the Revolution, I was thrilled. My favorite team was run by the same owners as my new soccer team. The Krafts have been brilliant for the Patriots, and from my brief research – four MLS Cup Finals? – it looked like they'd been good to the Revs, as well. In this light, I thought the shoulder pads on the Revs' kits were nothing more than a nifty little nod to the brotherhood. I never imagined it would be cause for some sort of wedge between the two teams. But the effect of these constant little snubs, the dismissal and favoritism, over the course of just one season for me, is that I find myself feeling guilty for pumping my fist as Wes Welker makes another fantastic catch fifteen yards downfield. I have to frequently remind myself that the Revolution and the Patriots  are not in fact rivals. I'd love for them to be brothers – equal in success, equal in prestige. And yes, prestige will come with time, and with success, for the Revs, but it also has to be something that is fought for. The Krafts shouldn't be pitting the Revolution against the Patriots.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: a:1:{i:0;s:61:"“Shh, I can't hear the crickets” – http://bit.ly/xVQWb9";}

item.dc:creator: bensaufley
item.content:encoded: I'm enough of a cynic not to take most stories and opinions about public figures as fact, and enough of an optimist to sometimes accept the impression I've been given despite its likely inaccuracy. There isn't a better example of this than Steve Jobs. He was a founder, and the CEO, of one of America's most rich and successful companies. He was the object of scorn from many open software advocates, and of scrutiny for things like the labor practices at Foxconn. He's also been credited with inventing the iPod, iPhone, and iPad – I wonder how many other engineers, designers, and developers are getting left out of that credit. As the head of Apple, he's taken what is probably a disproportionate amount of both criticism and praise for the company's business, though much of both is probably well-earned. But the man that I've put together in my head, from stories like this, and this, interviews like this[ref]And a few others that I can't seem to find right now…[/ref], things like this,[ref]Wired's tribute to Steve Jobs is on its front page – this link may break.[/ref] and videos of his keynotes and other speeches, seems like someone to look up to. The impression I've gotten, right or wrong, is one that I've really come to like. He seemed impassioned, creative, and intelligent. He seemed laid-back, but not ineffectual – more like relaxed, comfortable with who he was and what he was doing. He could be blunt, but he was rarely wrong. As a Democrat with a complicated relationship with objectivism, I see Jobs as a far better John Galt figure than many other CEOs today. Along with many of the founders of Silicon Valley, All of that – whether or not it's who the man truly was – is why I was so saddened to learn of Steve Jobs' passing, last night. Plus, he was a big part of Pixar's ascent. And Pixar, probably more than anything else, has made me the kind of person I am today. So …thanks, Steve.

item.title: Tyler Tolson - 2014-08-01 09:17:16
item.content:encoded:
Ben your profile on LinkedIn comes up on each query I run and I am quite impressed with your background and portfolio. The client I am conducting the search for is an industry leader and they are looking to bring on a Front-End Web Developer. How are things going at AdHarmonics? I think you will be impressed what this position has to offer in terms of compensation and benefits..
Ben- I would be negligent to not share with you what this full time opportunity, and how this position can lead to additional responsibility and growth. They Based near Burlington,MA and are actively looking to hire an additional Front-End Developer. . This is an outstanding opportunity to join 15 year old company. Their technology is used by some of the most recognizable online retailers, brands and companies in the world.
This role will be responsible for: - Confident in HTML5 and CSS - Working knowledge of Web languages such as PHP, Perl, ActionScript, or Ruby - Working knowledge of Apache and MySQL - Familiarity with responsive design coding concepts - I can email you the full job description if you would like
Would you be interested in learning more? If so, let’s set up a time to discuss this in greater detail. Alternatively, please feel free to forward this to any appropriate contact or candidate if it is not right for you personally. I appreciate your consideration and help Ben!

item.title: Laurie Davis - 2015-08-14 13:04:51
item.content:encoded:
Dear Ben,
I am writing to follow up on the note I sent you via LinkedIn. You have an impressive profile and website and I am hoping to connect with you; even just to network. I support recruiting efforts for Deloitte’s VizStudio. We are a fun, innovative and creative data visualization practice that works on rapid prototyping for our clients across a variety of industries and functions using the most relevant tools and technologies. Our team is multi-disciplinary, consisting of business analysts, data scientists and design professionals. We are very interested in learning more about your career aspirations and accomplishments. Let me know if you might have 30 minutes to speak one day next week.
I appreciate your time and look forward to hearing from you.
Laurie A. Davis 202-441-3337 ldavis@deloitte.com <!--more--> AUTHOR: Laurie Davis AUTHOR EMAIL: ldavis@deloitte.com AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: New correspondence at BenSaufley.com IP: 108.31.86.111 Array ( [1_Name] => Laurie Davis [2_Email] => ldavis@deloitte.com [3_Comment] => Dear Ben,

Our team is multi-disciplinary, consisting of business analysts, data scientists and design professionals. We are very interested in learning more about your career aspirations and accomplishments. Let me know if you might have 30 minutes to speak one day next week.
I appreciate your time and look forward to hearing from you.
Laurie A. Davis 202-441-3337 ldavis@deloitte.com )

item.title: Sun Par - 2015-12-08 12:47:29
item.content:encoded:
Hi Ben,
I recently tried contacting you through Linkedin and your website about a top agency in Boston in need of a Web Developer. I apologize if you've already decided to pass, but I think you're a great fit for the role which is why I'm reaching out again. If you are on the fence about it, here are some more details.
First off, they pay well and it'll be a bump up from your current role. The agency is a laid-back, family-like environment with a lot of respect for a healthy work-life balance. The developer team is a small tight group. You'd be working directly with the people making the decisions. There's an opportunity to grow and lead as the team grows. You would also have the opportunity to work across multiple accounts and clients.
They're looking for someone with strong front-end and back-end skills. The person in this position MUST have deep experience in both .net & Open Source technologies on both web/mobile experience.
Thanks Ben, looking forward to hearing from you!
Sunny Park Creative Recruiter at BLT Recruiting sunny@bltrecruiting.com (W) 310.573.4000 (C) 917.428.1417 <!--more--> AUTHOR: Sun Par AUTHOR EMAIL: sunny@bltrecruiting.com AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: New correspondence at BenSaufley.com IP: 96.40.158.68 Array ( [1_Name] => Sun Par [2_Email] => sunny@bltrecruiting.com [3_Comment] => Hi Ben,
I recently tried contacting you through Linkedin and your website about a top agency in Boston in need of a Web Developer. I apologize if you've already decided to pass, but I think you're a great fit for the role which is why I'm reaching out again. If you are on the fence about it, here are some more details.
First off, they pay well and it'll be a bump up from your current role. The agency is a laid-back, family-like environment with a lot of respect for a healthy work-life balance. The developer team is a small tight group. You'd be working directly with the people making the decisions. There's an opportunity to grow and lead as the team grows. You would also have the opportunity to work across multiple accounts and clients.
They're looking for someone with strong front-end and back-end skills. The person in this position MUST have deep experience in both .net & Open Source technologies on both web/mobile experience.
Thanks Ben, looking forward to hearing from you!
Sunny Park Creative Recruiter at BLT Recruiting sunny@bltrecruiting.com (W) 310.573.4000 (C) 917.428.1417 )

They're looking for someone with strong front-end and back-end skills. The person in this position MUST have deep experience in both .net & Open Source technologies on both web/mobile experience.
Thanks Ben, looking forward to hearing from you!

item.title: On the Revolution, Marketing, and Supporters’ Group Relations
item.dc:creator: bensaufley
item.content:encoded:
M. Willis:
In reading the transcript of the event, the Revolution management team seems to say they feel bad too - but not on behalf of their fans. And they go on to say how much they’re shuffling things around - but not that they’re making the only changes that would amount to a show of respect to Revs supporters: substantial improvements to the quality and thoughtfulness of their own actions.
I’ve heard a lot of talk, since I started following the Revolution, about marketing and fan relations. I’ve talked about it a lot myself. But I have a couple of additions and counterpoints that I think need to be kept in mind. First, what I would love to see:
  1. A marketing campaign equal to that of Portland and others, free of the 90's faux-grunge aesthetic and with more dynamism, excitement, and frankly, production value.
  2. An owner, or someone from leadership – doesn't have to be a Kraft, I'll take Brian Bilello – who is as visible and as visibly excited about the team as Merritt Paulson, Joey Saputo, et al.
  3. A soccer-specific stadium that is in Boston or MBTA-accessible, and an accompanying brand realignment
  4. An invitation to Hogwarts.
I think Willis covered things like this pretty well – well, all but Hogwarts. Man, I'd totally be a Gryffindor. There are problems, though. This is not to make excuses for an organization that seems at times to be doing the minimum acceptable work for a team that is no longer particularly acceptable, but making sweeping demands like this isn't going to get the team or its supporters anywhere, and there are some things that need to be taken into account when assessing the current situation:
  1. I believe that Brian Bilello genuinely cares about the Revs, and about the supporters. I don't think that any press at the Supporters Summit intended to portray him unfairly, but without the full evening, at the very least on paper, I think it's hard to get a real grasp on the talks. Even extended quotes leave out a lot of the discussion that went on. I do think that he is actually frustrated about where the team is right now, but the safe PR move (see 2) is not to make a scene about it, but to do a Steve Nicol/Bob Bradley/Bill Belichick and say, “You know… it, uh, it is what it is. We obviously didn't do well. We have to try harder next time.”
  2. I get the impression that the organization as a whole doesn't want to rock the boat right now. And I can say – and you can say – “To hell with that, the boat is sinking,” as much as we want, but the reality is that probably, the team is pulling in OK numbers with youth soccer leagues, family trips, and the other amusement-style marketing segments. To the hardcore supporters, it certainly seems like the rest of the league is laughing at us and our attendance, but there are probably some economic metrics out there that say that the Revolution is doing OK. And working in marketing myself, I know how it can be when there are people who are outside of the real realm of the product that are guiding policy. I would imagine that there are at least a few people within the organization that would love to take some of Willis’s ideas, your ideas, and my ideas, and run with them – but there are brand restrictions,[ref]The talks required to mount a rebranding for a small organization are pretty immense – and here we’re talking about a sub-structure of the MLS organization.[/ref] budget restrictions,[ref]Of course, not a ton of money coming in means you have to reduce the money that's going out to stay in the black[/ref] and other restrictions besides that are likely tying a lot of hands. The counterargument to this, of course, is that you have to make that initial investment, and maybe dip into the red, in order to really turn this team around. But if they're to be believed – and I, for one, do believe it – that there are stadium plans in the works (though how far off I wouldn't guess), that does seem like a logical starting point for that kind of expenditure.
So what can be done in the short term? In my opinion, they're doing it – for the most part. The staff reorganization, while it was more of a reorganization than an upheaval, was certainly not small. The new team structure – from the new coach and his staff to the new position of strength and conditioning coach – is a step in the right direction. I'm unhappy with the decision not to replace their highly-publicized “First-Ever Designated Player,” but I'm going to reserve judgment there until I've at least seen them play in Tucson.
